PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The  Government  of  Inner  Mongolia  Autonomous  Region  (GIMAR)  envisions  the 
development of a low-carbon and clean energy-based district heating systems, contributing to 
more inclusive and sustainable livelihood in Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region (IMAR). As an 
important initiative, the Hohhot City Development Investment and Operation Company will test a 
wind and coal hybrid system in one of the three project sites. However, the scale of wind and 
coal hybrid district heating is marginal in the current project design. A comprehensive study is 
needed to clearly assess the potentials of expanding wind, and other renewable and/or clean 
energy-based district heating. To address this important requirement, the project preparatory 
technical assistance (PPTA) will be implemented in two parts. The first part of the PPTA will 
respond  to  this  need  by  conducting  a  thorough  analysis  on  the  potentials  of  clean  and 
renewable energy-based heating systems. It will examine technical and economic feasibility of 
the expansion of wind power and other renewable energy sources in district heating systems. It 
will also assess the impact of low-carbon district heating with and without renewable energy 
subsidies. The first part of the PPTA will propose and confirm possible expansion of renewable 
heating sources in the project. Since the project is classified as complex due to safeguards 
issues, part of the PPTA will pay attention on safeguards due diligence works.  
 
2.  The second part of PPTA will (i) conduct the due diligence on confirmed scope of the 
project;  (ii)  familiarize  the  implementing  agency  with  Asian  Development  Bank’s  (ADB’s) 
procurement  and  disbursement  procedures,  and  environment  and  social  safeguards 
requirements; and (iii) identify project risks and support the establishment and operation of a 
comprehensive risk management plan.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
4.  The PPTA is estimated to cost $600,000 to be financed on a grant basis from ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government will provide in-kind 
counterpart costs and services including counterpart staff, office space, furniture, administrative 
support services, and local city transport and logistics costs. The detailed cost estimate is in 
Table A4.2. The government was advised that the approval of the PPTA does not commit ADB 
to financing any ensuing project.

D.  Consulting Services 
5.  Part 1 of the PPTA will use individual consultants (3 international for 4.5 person-months, 
and 2 national for 16.0 person-months). This approach is cost and time efficient to allow quick 
mobilization of the consultants to (i) conduct the technical and economic study on wind and 
other renewable energy-based district heating, (ii) improve the project design, and (iii) conduct 
environmental and social safeguards due diligence. The tasks under part 2 will be undertaken 
by a consulting firm (1 international for 2.0 person-months and 4 national for 9.0 person-months) 
using quality-  and  cost-based  selection  method  (with  a  quality-cost  ratio  of  90:10)  due to 
important technical aspects associated with hybrid wind district heating system. Table A4.3 
provides the required positions and person-months of the consultants. 
 
6.  The procurement of equipment by consultants under the technical assistance (TA) will 
follow ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). The equipment 
procured under the TA will be turnover to the executing agency upon TA completion. The 
proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in line with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).

7.  The outline terms of reference for part 1 PPTA consultants are described in paras. 8 to 
12.   
 
8.  Energy  economist  (international,  1.0  person-month,  intermittent).The  expert  should 
have (i) a postgraduate degree in energy system, energy economics, or in any relevant field; (ii) 
at least 10 years of working experience in energy economics, and energy economic modeling; 
and (iii) a good command of English. The expert with experience in the region and or in the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC) will be an advantage. The expert will undertake the following 
activities: 
(i)  Conduct research on existing and projected wind farms in IMAR, focusing on 
installed capacity, production capacity, and wind power curtailment.   
(ii)  Conduct research on the potentials of alternative clean energy sources for district 
heating in Hohhot and IMAR, including natural gas, concentrated solar power, 
geothermal energy, and others.  
(iii)  Research on the electricity and heating tariff systems in Hohhot and  IMAR, 
including thorough investigation of the renewable energy subsidy scheme.  
(iv)  In close cooperation with the district heating specialist, and the electricity and 
district heating specialist, review the current heating tariff setting regime and 
investment support mechanism in Hohhot and IMAR, and assess its adequacy 
for promoting investment on clean and renewable-based district heating systems.  
(v)  In close cooperation with the district heating specialist, develop an excel-based 
model containing various scenarios to project electricity and heating demand up 
to 2025 with different mixture of energy sources.   
(vi)  In close cooperation with the district heating specialist, and the electricity and 
district heating specialist, develop an excel-based model with various scenarios 
on low-carbon heating system up to 2025. The consideration of with and/or 
without renewable energy must be incorporated in these scenarios.  
(vii)  Assess technical aspects of these low-carbon heating scenarios, and prepare 
and submit an analytical and technical report on low-carbon heating systems in 
close cooperation with the district heating specialist.  
(viii)  Recommend different tariff setting methodologies to accommodate clean energy-
based district heating system with and without a subsidy scheme.

(ix)  Recommend adequate heating tariff level and regime, and additional investment 
support  mechanism  for  clean  energy-based  heating  systems  in  Hohhot  and 
IMAR.  
(x)  Conduct  the  economic  analysis  following  ADB's  Guidelines  on  Economic 
Analysis of Investment Projects (1997). 
(xi)  Prepare  an  analytical  report  together  with  the  district  heating  specialist  and 
submit it to ADB. The report should be both in English and Chinese. 
 
9.  Environmental  impact  assessment  specialist  (international,  2.0  person-months, 
intermittent).  The  expert  should  (i)  have  a  postgraduate  degree  in  environmental  science, 
environmental engineering, environmental management, or in any relevant field; (ii) have at 
least 10 years of working experience; and (iii) be fluent in English. The expert with experience in 
the region and or in the PRC will be an advantage. The expert will undertake the following 
activities: 
(i)  Visit the project site to assess the status of project preparation and readiness 
and draw the estimated period for approval by relevant government authorities. 
(ii)  Review the domestic environmental impact assessment (EIA) reports prepared 
by local EIA institutes and feasibility study reports. 
(iii)  Identify information gap, and collect sufficient information through primary and 
secondary data collection. 
(iv)  Evaluate environmental impacts of the project, and identify environmental risks.  
(v)  Propose  a  set  of  environmental  mitigation  measures  throughout  the  project 
implementation,  and  recommend  environmentally-friendly  technologies 
particularly for the design and construction, which emphasizes on (a) biodiversity 
conservation, (b) public health and safety, (c) physical cultural resources, (d) 
pollution prevention and abatement, and (e) climate change mitigation including 
potential use of clean energy source.  
(vi)  Establish environmental baseline indicators and performance targets.  
(vii)  Assist the executing and implementing agencies in the stakeholders’ participation 
and consultation during preparation of an EIA report and disclosure of relevant 
information.  
(viii)  Assess  and  quantify  environment  benefits,  such  as  energy  efficiency 
improvements, emission reduction, and other associated environmental benefits. 
(ix)  Assist  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  to  prepare  a  sound 
environmental management plan and a grievance redress mechanism to address 
environmental concerns and problems raised by the project-affected people.  
(x)  Carryout cost review of the proposed environmental mitigation measures and 
implementation of the environmental management plan, and prepare a list of 
activities  and  budget  requirements  for  independent  environment  monitoring 
during project implementation.  
(xi)  Assess the capacity of executing and implementing agencies on environmental 
assessment, management, and monitoring; identify areas for improvement and 
training needs with respect to the environmental safeguard under the project; 
recommend required measures for capacity building; and prepare materials and 
conduct  the  training  workshop  to  the  staff  of  executing  and  implementing 
agencies, and other stakeholders on environmental management and safeguard.  
(xii)  Prepare  an  EIA  in  English  ensuring  to  meet  all  the  requirements  of  ADB 
Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) and submit it to ADB.   
(xiii)  Incorporate comments and feedbacks from ADB in regards to the EIA.

10.  Social  analysis  and  safeguards  specialist  (international,  1.5  person-months, 
intermittent). The expert should (i) have a postgraduate degree in social science, or in any 
relevant field; (ii) have at least 10 years of working experience; and (iii) be fluent in English. The 
expert with experience in the region and or in the PRC will be an advantage. The expert will 
undertake the following activities: 
(i)  Visit the project site and assess the land acquisition impact of the project and 
prepare  a  due  diligence  report  on  legacy  issue,  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement. 
(ii)  Assess  the  labor  retrenchment  issue  of  the  project,  and  prepare  a  labor 
retrenchment plan including the budget.  
(iii)  Provide supervision on data collection done by the national social analysis and 
safeguards specialist and conduct comparative social analysis by using collected 
data. 
(iv)  Assess  whether  the  project  would  not  have  any  adverse  impacts  on  ethnic 
minorities (Mongol neighborhoods), and whether they will benefit from the project 
proportionally. 
(v)  Assess affordability issues related to heating supply for the poor and households 
headed by women, review the current practices to help reduce the burden of the 
poor on heating tariff, recommend pro-poor and gender activities that could be 
included in the project and would directly benefit the poor and households headed 
by women in the project cities. 
(vi)  Assess  the  project’s  impact  on  health  including  avoided  carbon  monoxide 
poisoning and respiratory diseases by using coal stove, paying attention to the 
gender difference.  
(vii)  Assess the poverty reduction and social benefit associated with the project, and 
identify special measures to benefit the poor.  
(viii)  Identify an opportunity to mainstream a gender issue in the project, propose 
relevant activities, and prepare a gender action plan for the project.  
(ix)  Prepare and submit the social section of the project due diligence report in 
English, which includes poverty reduction and social strategy, labor retrenchment 
and reemployment plan, and gender action plan.  
 
11.  District  heating  specialist  (national,  13.0  person-month,  intermittent).  The  expert 
should have (i) a postgraduate degree in heating engineering, or in any relevant field; (ii) at least 
10 years of engineering experience in district heating and similar projects, and 5 years of 
experience in ADB procurement or other multinational development bank-financed projects; (iii) 
at least 3 years of working experience in ADB-financed loan projects; and (iv) a good command 
of English. The expert will undertake the following activities: 
(i)  Coordinate with all other experts in part one of the PPTA on the assignment to 
ensure the quality and timely delivery of work. 
(ii)  Liaise  with  ADB,  executing  agency,  and  implementing  agency  during  the 
implementation of the PPTA. 
(iii)  Conduct research on the heating market in Hohhot and IMAR, analyzing heating 
demand trend between 2000 and 2012, changes in heating energy sources, and 
associated technology development.  
(iv)  Conduct research on the electricity market in Hohhot and IMAR, analyzing the 
growth trend between 2000 and 2012, types of power sources and associated 
technologies, and the grid stability and capacity.  
(v)  In close cooperation with the energy economist and the electricity and district 
heating specialist, analyze and discuss the system capacity, stability, and other

technical aspects of the electricity power grid systems in Hohhot and IMAR under 
the different scenarios on future district heating systems. 
(vi)  In close cooperation with the energy economist and the electricity and district 
heating specialist, prepare and submit an analytical and technical report on future 
district heating systems in IMAR both in English and Chinese.  
(vii)  Review  the  current  project  design  and  propose  feasible  options  to  improve 
project design taking into account the capacity of the project implementation 
agency, available technologies, financial and economic aspects of the project, 
project timeline, and other factors that influence the project design. The proposal 
to improve the project design can be supported by developed scenarios on 
electricity and heating markets.  
(viii)  Assess the status of project preparation and readiness and draw the estimated 
period for approval by relevant government authorities. 
(ix)  Evaluate the technical issues for the project by reviewing background data and 
feasibility report, and if possible, provide suggestions on how to improve the 
project design to enhance the energy efficiency of the project. 
(x)  Estimate the preliminary heating demand of the project, predict future heating 
demand, and establish solid assumptions for the projections in conjunction with 
the financial analyst and the economic analyst in the team. 
(xi)  Assess heat capacity, heat production and integration, and design concept of a 
hybrid  coal  and  wind  district  heating  system  and  other  coal-based  heating 
sources.  
(xii)  Compare the design concept of a hybrid coal and wind district heating with the 
internationally  available  best  examples  of  wind  district  heating  technologies, 
identify any technical gaps, and propose alternatives to improve the system 
design for efficiency.  
(xiii)  Identify likely technical risks and other associated with various aspects of the 
project, and evaluate the viability of the project under these risks. 
(xiv)  Collect information on policies and regulations on demand side energy efficiency 
associated with district heating (e.g. building efficiency, district heating metering) 
(xv)  Lead to calculate the energy efficiency improvement, annual coal saving, and 
annual emission reduction of carbon dioxide and the other air pollutants of the 
project against its baseline conditions. 
(xvi)  Collect information to identify potential replication of a hybrid wind district heating 
system  in  other  parts  of  the  province  and  neighboring  provinces  with  similar 
conditions. And lead to calculate province-wide energy efficiency improvements of 
district heating when full potential of replicating wind district heating is reached in 
IMAR  and  other  provinces.  Its  associated  annual  coal  savings,  and  other 
environmental benefits, including annual emission reduction of carbon dioxide and 
the other air pollutants should be also calculated. Perform such analysis against 
the province’s energy efficiency, and emission reduction targets. 
(xvii)  Conduct procurement capacity assessment of the executing and implementing 
agencies and submit the results of assessment to ADB. 
(xviii)  Prepare and submit a procurement plan and financing packages  
(xix)  Assist  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  in  preparing  an  advance 
procurement plan. 
(xx)  Review  relevant  bidding  documents  for  advance  procurement,  which  will  be 
prepared by the implementing agency or the design institute of the project, and 
revise them to meet ADB standards. Translate bidding documents into English 
and submit it for ADB’s review.

12.  Social analysis and safeguards specialist (national, 3.0 person-months, intermittent). 
The expert should have (i) a postgraduate degree in social science, or in any relevant field; (ii) 
at least 8 years of working experience; and (iii) a good command of English. The expert will 
undertake the following activities: 
(i)  Visit the project site and assess the land acquisition impact of the project and 
prepare a diligence report on legacy issue in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard 
Policy Statement. 
(ii)  Assess  the  labor  retrenchment  issue  of  the  project,  and  prepare  a  labor 
retrenchment plan including the budget.  
(iii)  Collect  basic  socioeconomic  indicators  such  as  (a)  total  population  and 
households; (b) total households headed by women; (c) poverty ratio; (d) major 
industries  and  sources of  income; (e)  number  of  existing  and  proposed  low 
income housings; (f) incidence of carbon monoxide poisoning and respiratory 
diseases; and (g) number of heating beneficiaries by subprojects disaggregated 
by gender, income group, and newly and existing connected households, in all 
subproject areas. Conduct comparative analysis by using such data.  
(iv)  Assess  whether  the  project  would  not  have  any  adverse  impacts  on  ethnic 
minorities (Mongol neighborhoods), and whether they will benefit from the project 
proportionally. 
(v)  Assess affordability issues related to heating supply for the poor and households 
headed by women, review the current practices to help reduce the burden of the 
poor on heating tariff, recommend pro-poor and gender activities that could be 
included in the project and would directly benefit the poor and households headed 
by women in the project cities. 
(vi)  Assess  the  project’s  impact  on  health  including  avoided  carbon  monoxide 
poisoning and respiratory diseases by using coal stove, paying attention to the 
gender difference.  
(vii)  Assess the poverty reduction and social benefit associated with the project, and 
identify special measures to benefit the poor.  
(viii)  Identify  an  opportunity  to  mainstream  gender  issue  in  the  project,  propose 
relevant activities, and prepare a gender action plan for the project.  
(ix)  Prepare and submit the social section of the project due diligence report in 
English, which includes poverty reduction and social strategy, labor retrenchment 
and reemployment plan, and gender action plan.  
 
13.   The outline terms of reference for PPTA part 2 consultants are described in paras. 14 to 
18.   
 
14.  Clean energy and district heating specialist/Team leader (international, 2.0 person-
months, intermittent). The expert should (i) have a postgraduate degree in heating engineering, 
electrical engineering, or in any relevant field; (ii) have at least 10 years of working experience 
in district heating projects; and (iii) be fluent in English. The expert with experience in the region 
and or in the PRC will be an advantage. Experience in electrode boiler for district heating is 
required. The expert will undertake the following activities: 
(i)  Coordinate with all other experts on the assignment to ensure the quality and 
timely delivery of work. 
(ii)  Responsible for the overall management of the project and liaise with ADB, 
executing agency, and implementing agency during the implementation of the 
PPTA.

(iii)  In close cooperation with the district heating specialist and the electricity and 
district  heating  specialist,  review  the  project  feasibility  study,  engineering 
designs, and other relevant document. 
(iv)  Prepare and submit the technical due diligence section for hybrid district heating 
system in line with other technical due diligence report of the project.   
(v)  Identify risks associated with hybrid district heating system and develop a risk 
management plan.  
(vi)  Prepare training materials on clean and renewable energy based district heating 
systems. Training materials should be written in English and be submitted to 
ADB. 
(vii)  Organize  and  conduct  training  sessions  on  renewable-based  district  heating 
system.  
(viii)  Organize and manage a study tour in a Danish wind district heating project. 
(ix)  Provide  technical  advice  and  support  to  the  district  heating  specialist  in  (a) 
preparing a procurement plan and financial packages, and (b) reviewing bidding 
documents that are relevant to the hybrid district heating system.  
 
15.  Electricity and district heating specialist (national, 3.0 person-months, intermittent). 
The expert should have (i) a postgraduate degree in electrical engineering, or in any relevant 
field; (ii) at least 5 years of working experience in the energy sector; (iii) experience in electrical 
and/or electrode boiler for district heating; and (iv) a good command of English. The expert will 
undertake the following activities: 
(i)  Conduct research on existing and projected wind farms in IMAR, focusing on 
installed capacity, production capacity, and wind power curtailment.   
(ii)  Conduct research on the potentials of alternative clean energy sources for district 
heating in Hohhot and IMAR, including natural gas, concentrated solar power, 
geothermal energy, and others.  
(iii)  Research on the electricity and heating tariff systems in Hohhot and  IMAR, 
including thorough investigation of the renewable energy subsidy scheme.  
(iv)  Assess technical aspects of these low-carbon heating scenarios, and prepare 
and submit an analytical and technical report on low-carbon heating systems in 
close cooperation with the district heating specialist. The report should be both in 
English and Chinese. 
(v)  Support the clean energy and district heating specialist in reviewing the project 
feasibility study, engineering designs, and other relevant document.  
(vi)  Support  the  clean  energy  and  district  heating  specialist  in  conducting  due 
diligence on hybrid district heating system, including the integration of different 
types of boilers, electrical control system, and other technical matters.  
(vii)  Support the clean energy and district heating expert in preparing the technical 
due diligence section for hybrid district heating system in line with other technical 
due diligence report of the project.    
(viii)  Identify risks associated with electrode boiler and system integration including 
electrical control system in particular, and develop a risk management plan.  
(ix)  Assist  the  clean  energy  and  district  heating  specialist  in  preparing  training 
materials on clean and renewable energy based district heating systems and 
training materials in Chinese and submit it to ADB. 
(x)  Organize and conduct training sessions in Chinese on clean and renewable 
energy-based boilers, including electrode boilers used in district heating system.   
(xi)  Provide Chinese translation during a study tour in a Danish wind district heating 
project.

(xii)  Support  the  district  heating  specialist  in  preparing  a  procurement  plan  and 
financial  packages  relevant  to  electrode  boiler  and  its  control  system;  and 
reviewing relevant bidding documents. 
 
16.  Environment specialist (national, 3.0 person-months, intermittent). The expert should 
have  (i)  a  postgraduate  degree  in  environmental  science,  environmental  engineering, 
environmental management, or in any relevant field; (ii) at least 5 years of working experience; 
and (iii) a good command of English. The expert will undertake the following activities:  
(i)  Visit  the  project  site  and  review  the  domestic  EIA  reports  to  assess  its 
completeness. 
(ii)  Translate domestic EIA, feasibility study, energy assessment reports in English 
and submit them to ADB 
(iii)  Identify  information  gap,  collect  sufficient  information  through  primary  and 
secondary data collection. 
(iv)  Identify any major risks associated with environmental related issues, and make 
preliminary  assessment  whether  adequate  mitigation  measures  have  been 
proposed. 
(v)  Perform a preliminary assessment of the environmental benefits from project 
implementation, including (a) energy efficiency improvements, (b) reductions in 
air emissions, and (c) other environmental benefits.  
(vi)  Estimate emission reductions of main pollutants as a result of the project, based 
on the number of boilers to be removed within the service areas of the project.  
(vii)  Propose  and  review  the  costs  of  the  proposed  environmental  mitigation 
measures and implementation of the environmental monitoring plan. 
(viii)  Assist the EIA specialist in preparing the EIA of the project. 
 
17.  Financial analyst (national, 1.5 person-months, intermittent). The expert should have (i) 
a postgraduate degree in finance, or in any relevant field; (ii) at least 5 years of working 
experience; (iii) a recognized accounting qualification (e.g., Chartered Accountant or Chartered 
Professional Accountant); and (iv) a good command of English. The expert will undertake the 
following activities: 
(i)  Conduct the financial viability analysis of the project1 by (a) deriving the key 
financial indicators such as the net present value,2 financial internal rate of return

undisbursed balance of the loan. There are no front-end fees. Cost Escalation Factors: For price 
contingency  estimates,  ADB  suggested  cost  escalation  factors  should  be  used.  Updates  can  be 
obtained at: http://lnadbg1.asiandevbank.org/erd0004p.nsf/.

and weighted average cost of capital; (b) assessing the debt service coverage 
using the cash flows generated by the proposed project under the proposed off-
take heating tariff; and (c) conducting sensitivity analysis.   
(ii)  Conduct financial viability gap analysis for the project based on the proposed 
heating  tariff,  finalized  project  scope,  cost  estimate,  investment  plan,  and 
implementation schedule. Develop a financial viability gap filling strategy in case 
of a financial gap when cost overrun exceeds the contingencies provided.  
(iii)  Review  the  audited  and  unaudited  financial  statements  of  the  implementing 
agency for the past 3 years to assess (a) historical financial performance, (b) 
heating tariffs, (c) capital structure, and (d) sufficient generation of internal funds 
to support sustainability of ongoing operations (i.e., the ability to service existing 
debts and to finance a reasonable proportion of capital expenditures). 
(iv)  Discuss  the  current  internal  and  external  audit  arrangements  as  part  of the 
financial  management  assessment  and  the  requirements  of  ADB's  Public 
Communications Policy (2011). 
(v)  Prepare  and  submit  projected  financial  statements  (balance  sheet,  income 
statement, and statement of cash flows) for the next 10 years. Design the funds 
flow  and  disbursement  arrangements  based  on  the  financial  management 
assessment conducted on the implementing agency including financial ratios 
analysis. 
(vi)  Assess the financial management capabilities, the organizational structure and 
internal controls of the implementing agency,3 confirm whether the funds flow and 
disbursement mechanisms are properly designed, and recommend institutional 
strengthening and capacity building during the PPTA phase.  
(vii)  Review  the  commercial  performance  of  the  implementing  agency  (e.g., 
generation of an acceptable rate of return on assets) so as to assess, from a 
commercial perspective, their capacity to efficiently construct and operate the 
assets to be funded by the project.  
(viii)  Prepare and submit the financial management assessment, and the financial 
analysis section of the project due diligence report. 
(ix)  If performance shortcomings are identified, recommend either (a) measures that 
can  correct  for  these  shortcomings,  or  (b)  if  the  shortcomings  cannot  be 
corrected, practical alternative approaches to construction and operation of the 
assets. 
 
18.  Economic analyst (national, 1.5 person-months, intermittent). The expert should have 
(i) a postgraduate degree in economics, or in any relevant field; (ii) at least 10 years of working 
experience;  and  (iii)  a good command  of  English. The  expert  will  undertake  the following 
activities: 
(i)  Perform  the  economic  analysis  for  the  proposed  project  following  ADB’s 
Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects (1997) specifically including (a) 
heating demand analysis, (b) least-cost and equalizing discount rate analysis, 
(c) adjusting the financial costs and benefits to border/shadow prices, and (d) risk 
and sensitivity analysis.

(ii)  Identify quantitative and qualitative costs and benefits; either and/or both fuel 
savings and/or the willingness-to-pay for heating by consumers in the project 
area. 
(iii)  Propose methodologies to quantify the economic value of environmental benefits 
to be included in the economic analysis following ADB’s Economic Valuation of 
Environmental  Impacts:  A Workbook  (1996),  and  Environmental  Assessment 
Guidelines (2003). 
(iv)  Prepare and submit the economic analysis section of the project due diligence 
report. 
(v)  Conduct a benchmarking of the technical and cost efficiency of the implementing 
agency so as to assess, from a technical perspective, their capacity to efficiently 
construct and operate the assets to be funded by the project. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
20.  The executing agency will be GIMAR and the implementing agency will be Hohhot City 
Development  Investment  and  Operation  Company.  The  project  management  office  will  be 
established within the implementing agency. The executing and implementing agencies will 
provide sufficient support to the PPTA consultants, which includes (i) arranging meetings with 
relevant government agencies and other institutes relevant to the project due diligence; (ii) 
providing access to all data which is permitted by the PRC law, including documents, reports, 
accounts, drawings and maps, and permission to enter offices, as appropriate and necessary, to 
undertake the work; (iii) arranging all the project site visits; (iv) providing a suitably furnished 
office with utilities and telecommunication access, and (iv) accommodating city transportation 
for consultants. The PPTA will be implemented over a period of 25 months. Part 1 is expected 
to start on 1 August 2013 and end on 31 January 2014 and part 2 is expected to start on 1 
February 2014 and end on 31 August 2014. The proposed PPTA and implementation schedule
